nodes.title: Afghanistan has plunged into poverty, with foreign aid frozen by sanctions on the Taliban. Nearly five million Afghans are likely to suffer severe malnutrition this year, the UN says. By one estimate, 90% of hospitals may close in the next few months. https://t.co/SU2Jn6J3dz

nodes.title:
A Florida teenager said that Elon Musk offered him $5,000 to stop tracking his private jet and posting its location on Twitter. He countered: How about $50,000? Or a Tesla Model 3? Or an internship?

The exchange went silent after Jan. 23. https://t.co/hdgk43YdD3 https://t.co/FRlb5RY3sg
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Tech giants are feeling the effects of Apple making it harder to track people online. This week, Meta said those changes cost it billions this year. Then its stock price fell more than 26% on Thursday, wiping more than $230 billion off its market value. https://t.co/Zndm95xB7H
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
A teacher at a New York Jewish school was asked last summer about a blog post she had written criticizing Israel. 

The teacher, who is Jewish, told her boss she would not discuss politics in class, and he praised her. A week later, she was fired. https://t.co/jNKRsns2hn

nodes.title: A Biden administration official said the ISIS leader Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi died at the start of a U.S. raid in Syria when he blew himself up with an explosive that also took out members of his family. At least 13 were killed in the operation. https://t.co/uT4WXE6m0v
